The latest Bond film has No Time for Culture Wars

25/10/2021

Sophia Andrews Gamarra examines the polarising cultural debates surrounding No Time To Die and how they affect the end product

Image by MGM

By Ed Halford

The following article contains heavy spoilers for No Time to Die

Last month saw the release of No Time to Die, the latest Bond film, which has been delayed since 2019 due to the COVID-19 pandemicâ€™s mass closure of cinemas.

It goes without saying that an upcoming Bond film, with its global cultural clout, generates a lot of buzz online. But this unprecedented delay left fans to stew, with almost two years to dissect trailers, interviews, and anything that fueled speculation. And as the last decade saw the rise of social media and greater public discussions of social justice, the conversation quickly turned to diversity. This often denotes diversity of gender and ethnicity, and itâ€™s a familiar term in online culture wars.

How, then, can these cultural rifts be defined? To generalise, â€˜culture warsâ€™ are waged on Twitter and other social media giants, concerning issues like social equality or Western cultural identity, creating a left-wing/right-wing battleground. Factions of the left argue that pop culture privileges stories of straight, white, able-bodied, cisgender men, and so creators have a moral responsibility to represent those who do not fit this criteria. Elements of the right contrarily believe that to do so is didactic â€˜virtue signallingâ€™, sacrificing the quality as a means of endorsing identity politics. The accused are subsequently described as â€˜wokeâ€™. â€˜Wokeâ€™ is Black American slang, meaning â€˜alert to social injusticeâ€™, but in this context, itâ€™s an insult, synonymous with â€˜self-satisfied, moralising, censoriousâ€™. To reinforce how simplistic this generalisation is, a YouGov poll found that 59% of Britons donâ€™t even know what â€˜wokeâ€™ means.

Back to No Time to Die. Around July 2019, online commentators went into a stir over the news that 007 would be played by Black actress Lashana Lynch. James Bond, like the Doctor in Doctor Who, is a character with a precedent of multiple incarnations. Therefore, when discussing diversity, the question of â€œWhen will he be female or non-white?â€ comes up. While some believe itâ€™s the obvious moral answer to make this character female or non-white, others will interpret any decision to do so as â€˜wokeâ€™. For the writers, there is no neutral option.

But for No Time to Die, they did something different, and needless to say, the publicity team ran with it. A headline like â€˜007 played by Black actressâ€™ was built for outrage clicks, from those who think everything is getting too â€˜wokeâ€™. However, if you read the article, youâ€™d quickly learn that in the plot, Bond has left MI6 and a new agent has inherited the codename. Even so, fans wondered if Bond losing his famous codename meant heâ€™d be sidelined in favour of new blood. It was also announced that Phoebe Waller-Bridge, of Fleabag fame, would contribute to the script, bringing not only more jokes, but a feminist perspective to the franchise.

Yet, was this stirring up of the â€˜culture warsâ€™ just for publicity? Did it change the Bond series as we know it, to have a new 007 or input from a feminist comedy writer? Well, yes and no.

In the film, a retired Bond is drawn back into the world of espionage, as he must defeat Safin, a new villain threatening to kill millions with a DNA-coded bio-weapon. To do so, he must work with Nomi, the new 007.

Going into it, I wondered if the â€˜culture warsâ€™ would be embodied by these two characters. Bond is a fiftysomething rich white man, who finds himself replaced by a young Black woman, highly skilled in the job and suspicious of her predecessor. In the face of passionate, sometimes vitriolic commentary online, the film brings something else to the table: levity. Nomi and Bond may be stern, battle-hardened operatives, but the rivalry between the two characters is depicted as childish. When theyâ€™re both hunting down the unscrupulous scientist Obruchev, Nomi makes a sarcastic wave when she spots Bond arrive in Cuba. When approaching Mâ€™s office, they make little digs about who he wants to see. Itâ€™s clear they find each other irritating, but thereâ€™s no real malice.

A sore spot is Bondâ€™s loss of his iconic codename. But as they work together and gain respect for each other, Nomi requests he have it back, conceding that itâ€™s â€œjust a numberâ€. While I thought it would be more meaningful if she kept it, to symbolise passing the torch, itâ€™s a reminder that the film is, at its core, a swansong for Daniel Craigâ€™s Bond.

No Time to Die portrays Nomi as a skilled and suave agent, with no-one calling attention to her gender or race, in appreciation or derision. The only overt mention of her race is during the filmâ€™s climax. As she holds Obruchev at gunpoint over the toxic water he created, he taunts her by suggesting the bio-weapon could wipe out the â€œAfrican diasporaâ€. To this she says, â€œTime to dieâ€, and pushes him in.

Itâ€™s odd that this reveal comes at a point where the villain is nearing defeat. But the scene represents the Bond series at its core: its wish-fulfillment. Itâ€™s always been a juvenile fantasy of a powerful man jetting off to exotic locations, equipped with exciting technology to hunt the bad guys, all while copulating with a string of beautiful women.

It follows that if the Bond series was to tackle sensitive social issues like diversity, it would still prioritise its sense of fun. Nomi dunking a racist in his own poison water is a cathartic fantasy, crowd-pleasing stuff that doesnâ€™t have much to say about racism itself, but then it doesnâ€™t seem to want to.

Itâ€™s a similar story with Bondâ€™s treatment of women in the film. His trademark womanising isnâ€™t condemned, but instead played for laughs. When he meets CIA agent Paloma, sheâ€™s the picture of a Bond girl, yet has none of a Bond girlâ€™s attitude. Sheâ€™s not mysterious and alluring, but an excited newbie to the CIA, just happy to be there. When Bond flirts with her as she takes off his shirt, she looks confused and passes him a disguise. Thereâ€™s no revulsion, only cheerful awkwardness, and Bond doesnâ€™t seem bothered at not getting sex. Later on, he compliments her on her skills, with no ulterior motive but rather, mere respect for a colleague.

No Time to Die has changed the franchise's politics but does so without self-congratulatory fanfare. Rather than commenting on Bondâ€™s historical lack of diversity and casual sexism, the film embraces the changing times without protest or apology. Nomi is an expert MI6 agent, and none of the good guys even consider this to be at odds with her being neither white nor male. Paloma is a beautiful woman who doesnâ€™t try to sleep with Bond, and Bond doesnâ€™t care. And Bond is still himself: suave, confident, and able to effortlessly take down a score of faceless henchmen.
